oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Excavation for the garage and the Caretaker's house at Green Lakes State Park
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Almquist Green Lakes Collection contains photos of the building of Green Lakes State Park taken by the original park superintendent, Arvin H. Almquist. Caption reads, "Excavation for both The Garage and The Caretaker's House ('Otto's House') progresses. Otto Schwenn, a kindly old gentleman with a German accent, lived there as caretaker until the late part, or just after, WWII. (Richard Almquist) remember visiting Otto evenings after dinner and listening to news broadcasts as Edward R. Murrow intoned 'This...is London' during the war."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Generic picture of construction at Green Lakes State Park, with a note to Superintendent Almquist, aka "Swede," about the uselessness of such a picture
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Almquist Green Lakes Collection contains photos of the building of Green Lakes State Park taken by the original park superintendent, Arvin H. Almquist. Captions read, "Note to Superintedent Almquist, universally known as 'Swede,' about the uselessness of a generic picture," and "The Generic Picture." The note reads, "Swede: a picture like this is useless. It could be described as anything from the Rover Boys at Hunter Camp to the Lost Battalion."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Almquist, Arvin H., 1901-1959

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Horizontal gas engine used during the construction of Green Lakes State Park
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Almquist Green Lakes Collection contains photos of the building of Green Lakes State Park taken by the original park superintendent, Arvin H. Almquist. Caption reads, "The little 'One Lunger' horizontal gas engine shown at the left had an exposed rod and crankshaft with an oil cup on it that had to be filled now and then for lubrication. The intake valve operated by suction only, and was held closed by a relatively weak coil spring. Occasionally, the governor would stick and the non-counter balanced engine would speed up and physically hop around until it was caught and the intake valve held down (open) with the palm of someone's hand to stop the thing."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Almquist, Arvin H., 1901-1959
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: State parks & reserves; Construction;
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Green Lakes State Park; Onondaga county (N.Y.); Fayetteville (N.Y.); New York (State)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Home economics class: home nursing care
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Grace Smith Bryan, teacher, demonstrating home nursing care to four female students. According to the teacher Mrs. Grace Smith Bryan, donor of this photo, Fayetteville was the first in New York state to give high school credit for home economics classes, which at the time took place in the former Library building, on the second floor of 114 Genesee St., donated for village use by the Huntington Crouse family. Left to right: Grace Smith (Mrs. George A. Bryan), teacher, Grace Goodfellow, UIP, Letty Wright and Doris Potter, seated.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of Ellen Beard Crouse
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Ellen Beard Crouse. After the death of her husband, Robert Crouse, and her subsequent move to Syracuse, NY, she offered rooms in her home at 114 East Genesee Street to be used for a library. It served as the home of the Fayetteville Free Library in Fayetteville, NY. from 1906 until 1922. Photo taken in University Art Gallery, Syracuse, NY.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Horse-drawn carriages in Fourth of July parade 1910
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Horse-drawn carriages lined up in the Fourth of July parade in 1910 going up the old Genesee St. hill in Fayetteville, NY. A photo reprint published in the Eagle-Bulletin Dewitt News-Times, July 4, 1979 identifies the girls in the center carriage as the daughters of Frank Elisha Dawley and Carrie Barnes Dawley with their horse, Sparkle. The caption reads:""July 4th 10, Fayetteville, N.Y. 'No.8', Photo By Humphrey."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Home economics class: cooking
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eleven female students focused on the teacher's demonstration in the kitchen area beside a long table with racks and tableware on top. According to the teacher, Mrs. Grace Smith Bryan, Fayetteville was the first in New York state to give high school credit for a home economics class, which at the time took place in the former Fayetteville Library building, the second floor of 114 Genesee St., donated for village use by the Huntington Crouse family. Left to right: standing - Letty Wright, UIP, Bess McKee, Olive Elliot, UIP, Edwarda Collin, Laura Dawley Mathews; seated - Grace Goodfellow, Hilda Russell, Doris Potter, Myrtle Russell. Woman in white back to the camera is Grace Smith Bryan.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The caption reads: Mr. and Mrs. Dahlstrom on tandem owned by T.W. Carr. Pictured at the corner of Clinton and Walnut Streets, Fayetteville, NY. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Home economics class: laundry
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One female student on the left ironing while three female students on the right do laundry using mechanical washing machines along the wall in kitchen area. According to the teacher Mrs. Grace Smith Bryan, donor of the photo, Fayetteville was the first in New York state to give high school credit for a home economics class, which at the time took place in the former Fayetteville Library building, on the second floor of 114 Genesee St., donated for village use by the Huntington Crouse family. Left to right: Edwarda Collin, UIP, Letty Wright, and Doris Potter.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Members of the Fayetteville Cycle Riders Club. Fayetteville Union School is in the background. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Coterie meeting in 1925
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A meeting of a local women's club, Coterie, on September 4, 1925, hosted by Elizabeth Palmer Erkenbeck. Description on the back of the photo reads: " Back row from left to right: Nellie Smith Wilber, Mrs. Robert Beard of Cortland, Zada Palmer, Hattie Dewey Jennings of Canastota, Carrie Stearns, Geneva Armstrong, Anna Armstrong, Collin Armstrong of Scarsdale, NY, Josie Beard, Kate Palmer, and Mrs. Ernest Edwards. Seated from left to right: Lucy Seward Noble, Dillie Serris Hall, Sarah Gillette Collin, Elizabeth Palmer Erkenbeck - hostess, Miriam Collin, Lillian M. Noble.
